Lastly, here is a clear & helpful explanation of brain death from the NHS:

Clear, compassionate communication is so vitally important in these kinds of cases.

Not just between medics & families - between the media & the public too.

Otherwise emotions run high & can be exploited.

A plea then. For measured, thoughtful, accurate words from us all.

Some of the coverage of this case has been exemplary, but not all. 

I dearly wish all journalists / commentators would ensure their reports of this case are clear, unambiguous & based in fact. 

Otherwise they risk confusing & inflaming what is already a desperate situation.

Archie's life support is *not* being withdrawn because his medical team are callous, unchristian, paternalistic or authoritarian.

He is - tragically - a child who has no prospect of recovery, & who is very likely, medically & legally, already to be braindead.

Nevertheless, based on there being no prospect of recovery or improvement for Archie (& on his treatment being intrusive & compromising of his dignity & autonomy - protracting death rather than prolonging life), Mr Justice Hayden concluded that ventilation should be stopped: https://t.co/6UsdNFqbaW

On appeal in July however, the appeal judge Mr Justice Hayden concluded that without the formal brain death testing, it was wrong to conclude death had occurred.

Death, he said, is a "stage beyond diagnosis" & so Archie was, still, technically alive: 

https://t.co/20x8rE8CDE
This evidence, plus second opinions from independent doctors, led Mrs Justice Arbuthnott to conclude that Archie had medically & legally died in May: https://t.co/jnUCJuNau0

However, there is overwhelming additional evidence to suggested conclusively that Archie is brain dead, as detailed in the court ruling:

- He has no blood flow through his brain stem
- His brain stem is necrotic
- His brain stem has been pushed out of the skull into the spine

Archie Battersbee's case is slightly more complicated (I'll explain why in a moment).

But this is *not* - as some newspapers & commentators have reported - because he is not brain dead.

Mrs Justice Arbuthnott's ruling from 13.6.22 explains this clearly:

https://t.co/1pExayGY6g

But there is no avoiding the devastating fact that the person will not ever regain consciousness or start breathing on their own again. 

They have already died.

It can be immensely painful & bewildering for families to see their loved one looking as though they are simply asleep - warm, flushed, chest rising & falling - yet be told that they have died.

Teams do their utmost to be as clear & compassionate as we can in our communication.

This, of course, is how we have the exceptionally altruistic gift of organ donation. A family whose loved one is brain dead (but whose body is being kept alive by machinery in intensive care) may decide to gift their organs to others with failing hearts / lungs / livers etc.

*But* it is possible to keep the body of someone who is brain dead/brain stem dead artificially alive using intensive care machinery such as a ventilator. The ventilator pushes air in and out of the lungs, in the absence of signals or commands from the brain stem.

In the UK, brain death refers to brain stem death.

A person whose brain stem has died (e.g. through prolonged lack of oxygen) has no possible chance of recovery. Their body is unable to survive without artificial life support.

The person has legally died.

The brain stem is the lower part of the brain that's connected to the spinal cord.

The brain stem is responsible for regulating most of the body's automatic functions that are essential for life, including:

- breathing
- heartbeat
- blood pressure
- swallowing

Brain death is not the same as coma, persistent vegetative state or locked-in syndrome.

Brain death means the permanent, irreversible & complete loss of brain function.

Most, but not all, definitions of 'brain death' include the death of the brain stem.
